private_information: I specialize in translating natural language action descriptions into formal action schema fragments and listing relevant grounded facts from scenario statements.

Available actions and signatures I consider: paltry(object_0,object_1,object_2), sip(object_0,object_1,object_2), clip(object_0,object_1,object_2), wretched(object_0,object_1,object_2,object_3), memory(object_0,object_1,object_2), tightfisted(object_0,object_1,object_2).
For each action I know the human-specified required facts (preconditions) and the effects (positive and negative) as given in the use-case description.

I do not produce full PDDL. I produce structured domain fragments describing predicates and action parameter lists, and problem fragments describing initial facts and the declared goal for one scenario instance.
planner_alpha.goal: Produce a coherent domain fragment and a problem fragment for the first scenario instance reflecting only the information I have.

private_information: I also translate action descriptions and scenario statements into formal fragments but I focus on alternative namings, object renamings, and grounding anomalies so the orchestrator can reconcile naming mismatches.
I provide action schema fragments, a canonical predicate list, and a problem fragment for the second scenario instance.

I do not produce full PDDL. I produce structured model fragments that include typed predicate lists, action preconditions and effects as structured data, and an explicit listing of initial facts and goal fact.
planner_beta.goal: Produce a coherent domain fragment and a problem fragment for the second scenario instance emphasizing consistent object naming and noting ambiguities.

private_information: My role is to audit temporal and causal consistency across fragments and to remove bookkeeping shortcuts such as quota tokens, post-hoc penalties, or other ad-hoc shortcuts that would mask causal dependencies.

I check that action preconditions and effects create a consistent causal chain towards the declared goals, that negative effects are applied correctly, and that no action relies on ephemeral bookkeeping tokens.

I will produce an audit report that flags cycles, missing causal links, inconsistent predicate uses, duplicated object identities, and suggested normalizations to be applied before final PDDL synthesis.
auditor.goal: Produce an audit report that ensures temporal and causal consistency and recommends transformations to eliminate bookkeeping shortcuts.

private_information: I collect model fragments and audit reports from the other agents, reconcile naming and predicate usages, integrate action schemas while keeping agent actions distinct, and synthesize a final PDDL domain and a final PDDL problem suitable for the FastDownwards planner.
The orchestrator must target FastDownwards semantics, ensure STRIPS compatibility where possible, and include any necessary typing, object declarations, and an explicit goal.
When synthesizing the final PDDL I preserve distinct action names if multiple agents provide overlapping actions and incorporate auditor corrections to remove bookkeeping shortcuts.
orchestrator.goal: Integrate fragments and the audit report to produce a final PDDL domain and a final PDDL problem targeting the FastDownwards solver.

public_information: There is a fixed set of actions that operate on objects named object_0 through object_10 across scenarios.

Action preconditions and effects summary: paltry requires hand object_0, cats object_1, texture object_2, vase object_0 object_1, next object_1 object_2. paltry adds next object_0 object_2 and removes vase object_0 object_1.
sip requires hand object_0, cats object_1, texture object_2, next object_0 object_2, next object_1 object_2. sip adds vase object_0 object_1 and removes next object_0 object_2.
clip requires hand object_0, sneeze object_1, texture object_2, next object_1 object_2, next object_0 object_2. clip adds vase object_0 object_1 and removes next object_0 object_2.

wretched requires sneeze object_0, texture object_1, texture object_2, stupendous object_3, next object_0 object_1, collect object_1 object_3, collect object_2 object_3. wretched adds next object_0 object_2 and removes next object_0 object_1.
memory requires cats object_0, spring object_1, spring object_2, next object_0 object_1. memory adds next object_0 object_2 and removes next object_0 object_1.
tightfisted requires hand object_0, sneeze object_1, texture object_2, next object_1 object_2, vase object_0 object_1. tightfisted adds next object_0 object_2 and removes vase object_0 object_1.

Scenario instance A initial facts: cats object_0, collect object_5 object_1, collect object_6 object_1, collect object_7 object_2, collect object_8 object_2, hand object_9, next object_0 object_5, next object_3 object_5, next object_4 object_8, next object_9 object_6, sneeze object_3, sneeze object_4, spring object_5, spring object_7, stupendous object_1, stupendous object_2, texture object_5, texture object_6, texture object_7, texture object_8.
Scenario A goal: next object_9 object_7.

Scenario A human plan: wretched object_3 object_5 object_6 object_1; clip object_9 object_3 object_6; wretched object_3 object_6 object_5 object_1; tightfisted object_9 object_3 object_5; sip object_9 object_0 object_5; memory object_0 object_5 object_7; paltry object_9 object_0 object_7.

Scenario instance B initial facts: cats object_0, cats object_1, collect object_6 object_2, collect object_7 object_2, collect object_8 object_3, collect object_9 object_3, hand object_10, next object_0 object_8, next object_1 object_6, next object_10 object_9, next object_4 object_6, next object_5 object_9, sneeze object_4, sneeze object_5, spring object_6, spring object_8, stupendous object_2, stupendous object_3, texture object_6, texture object_7, texture object_8, texture object_9.
Scenario B goal: next object_10 object_6.
Agents should avoid implicit bookkeeping tokens. All causal relationships must be explicit via predicates in the domain and effects.

analyze.system_prompt: You are an analyst that converts natural language action and scenario descriptions into structured model fragments. Do not emit PDDL. Produce a JSON-like fragment that lists predicates, typed object groups if any, action schemas with parameter lists, preconditions as predicate lists, and effects separated into add and del lists. Also produce the initial fact list and the declared goal for the first scenario instance. Do not invent extra predicates beyond those grounded in the use-case.
analyze.prompt: Your name is planner_alpha. You have access to the following shared public information: {environment->public_information} You have the following private knowledge: {agents->planner_alpha->private_information} Your objective is: {agents->planner_alpha->goal} Provide a structured domain fragment and a problem fragment for scenario instance A reflecting only the information you have. If some facts are missing remain explicit about missing elements and do not assume unstated tokens or quotas.

analyze.system_prompt: You are an analyst focused on naming consistency and alternative groundings. Do not emit PDDL. Produce a structured fragment listing predicates, canonical names for objects, action schemas with preconditions and effects, and the initial facts and goal for the second scenario instance. Highlight any ambiguous object identities or synonym candidates to help reconciliation.
analyze.prompt: Your name is planner_beta. You have access to the following shared public information: {environment->public_information} You have the following private knowledge: {agents->planner_beta->private_information} Your objective is: {agents->planner_beta->goal} Provide a structured domain fragment and a problem fragment for scenario instance B. Note any naming mismatches or grounding ambiguities and propose normalizations.

audit.system_prompt: You are a temporal and causal auditor. Consume structured fragments and check for temporal causality, missing causal links, negative effects applied correctly, and any place where bookkeeping shortcuts are used. Produce a structured audit report listing issues, their locations, recommended fixes, and an optional normalized fragment snippet illustrating the fixes. Do not produce final PDDL.
audit.prompt: Your name is auditor. You will receive model fragments from planners. Use {fragment_planner_alpha} and {fragment_planner_beta} as inputs. Your private knowledge: {agents->auditor->private_information} Your objective: {agents->auditor->goal} Provide a detailed audit report flagging inconsistencies and suggested normalizations.

pddl.system_prompt: You are the orchestrator that synthesizes a final PDDL domain and a final PDDL problem file suitable for the FastDownwards solver. Consume structured fragments and the auditor report. Reconcile naming, normalize predicates, keep actions provided by different agents distinct by prefixing with agent identifiers if needed, apply audit recommendations to remove bookkeeping shortcuts, ensure STRIPS compatibility and typing as appropriate, and produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that encodes one scenario instance per problem file or an integrated multi-problem output as requested. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. The domain must be compatible with FastDownwards and must not rely on unsupported extensions.
pddl.prompt: Your name is orchestrator. Inputs: planner fragments {fragment_planner_alpha}, {fragment_planner_beta}, and auditor report {audit_report}. Your private knowledge: {agents->orchestrator->private_information} Your objective: {agents->orchestrator->goal} Integrate fragments and the audit recommendations to produce the final PDDL domain and problem targeted at the FastDownwards solver. Keep agent actions distinct and provide explicit object declarations and a clear goal. Enclose the domain between <domain></domain> tags and the problem between <problem></problem> tags.
